;;新西兰总理克里斯·希普金斯
;

;新西兰总理克里斯·希普金斯检测结果呈阳性因感染 Covid-19，他将在 10 月 14 日大选前休战五天的竞选活动。

;

;希普金斯的竞选团队取消了周日早上的计划，因为这位工党领袖在奥克兰醒来时感到身体不适。随后的测试显示，总理感染了新冠病毒，在竞选的关键阶段打乱了他的计划。

;
;

;;相关：;;主流不满：小党如何决定新选举的结果新西兰大选;

;
;

;“他从昨天开始出现感冒和流感症状。总理发言人表示，他将被隔离五天，或者直到检测结果呈阴性为止。

;

;“他将继续通过 Zoom 进行活动。”

;

;;在 Instagram 上的帖子;中，希普金斯表示他将尽力保持竞选活动的参与度远程。

;

;“混蛋！经过一个艰难的夜晚后，我今天早上醒来感觉非常不舒服，刚刚得到了这个测试结果，”他写道。

;

;“我在竞选活动中与新西兰人保持密切联系，我不希望将其传染给任何人，所以我将遵循指导并隔离几天，或者直到我得到阴性测试为止。”

;

;新西兰不再有强制隔离期，尽管希普金斯根据建议的健康建议选择这样做。

;

;这位 45 岁的人在新西兰竞选的关键阶段生病了，他领导的执政党工党;在民调中已经远远落后;。提前投票从 9 月 27 日开始对一些新西兰人开放，第三次领导人辩论定于周二晚上举行。

;;亲中国候选人穆罕默德·穆伊祖 (Mohamed Muizzu)，赢得了马尔代夫总统选举
;

;亲-中国候选人穆罕默德·穆伊祖 (Mohamed Muizzu) 赢得了周六在马尔代夫举行的总统选举，这一结果将再次颠覆该群岛与传统伙伴印度的关系。

;

;穆伊祖 (Mohamed Muizzu) 领导的政党在上次举行时主持了大量中国贷款的涌入。他在环礁国家中拥有权力，以其豪华海滩度假村和名人游客而闻名。

;

;他在决选中赢得了超过 54% 的选票，促使现任总统易卜拉欣·穆罕默德·萨利赫在午夜前不久承认失败.

;
;

;;相关：;;马尔代夫大选决选成为印度和中国之间的岔路;

;
; < “祝贺当选总统穆伊祖，”萨利赫在 X（前身为 Twitter）上写道。 “我也祝贺那些表现出和平与民主进程的人们。”

;

;穆伊祖在其政党竞选总部外短暂露面，敦促支持者不要庆祝，直到周日早上，届时竞选限制正式生效。结束。

;

;萨利赫将担任看守总统，直至其继任者于 11 月 17 日就职。

;

;这一结果颠覆了萨利赫自上任五年以来为使该国的外交姿态恢复对新德里的努力。多年前。

;

;穆伊祖在早期政府的发展计划中发挥了关键作用，部分资金来自中国“一带一路”基础设施倡议的财政慷慨。

;

;他在与中国共产党的一次会议上表示去年，该党官员表示，该党的重新执政将“为我们两国之间的牢固关系谱写新的篇章”。

;

;马尔代夫位于印度洋中部，横跨印度洋，具有重要的战略地位。世界上最繁忙的东西航道之一。

;

;穆伊祖的导师、前总统阿卜杜拉·亚明从中国大量借贷用于建设项目，并拒绝了印度。

;

;萨利赫于 2018 年当选出于对亚明日益独裁统治的不满，;指责他将国家推入中国债务陷阱;。

;

;亚明转向北京也引起了新德里的警觉，新德里与美国及其盟国一样对中国日益增强的自信感到担忧

;

;穆伊祖发誓要释放亚明，他目前因腐败罪在同一个监狱岛上服刑 11 年，他在任职期间曾在那里监禁过许多政治对手。

;

;在周六的短暂露面中，穆伊祖敦促即将离任的总统利用行政权力，将亚明软禁。

;

;周六投票的投票率为 85%，略高于第一轮投票本月早些时候举行。监督组织透明马尔代夫表示，发生了一些“选举暴力”事件，但没有具体说明更多细节。

;

;官员称，一名选民打破了塑料投票箱，但选票被保存下来，选举也没有中断。计数。警方报告称逮捕了 14 人，主要是因为拍摄了标记选票的照片并在社交媒体上分享。

;

;该武装团体由塞尔维亚列表党的副领导人米兰·拉多伊奇 (Milan Radoičić) 领导，该党是贝尔格莱德支持的代表北部塞尔维亚少数民族的政党。科索沃。拉多伊奇通过律师表示，他应对与科索沃警察的枪战负责，但没有解释塞族准军事部队携带的现代武器的来源。

;;绿色茎上有一个非常明亮的红辣椒，其他的辣椒在它后面模糊。辣椒看起来像糊状，近似矩形，但有无尽的脊线，底部有一条小尾巴。
;

;加拿大男子打破了他自己保持的世界纪录，用最快的时间吃掉了 50 个世界上最辣的辣椒随后又吃了 85 个。

;

;周二，吉尼斯世界纪录宣布，加拿大人迈克·杰克 (Mike Jack) 在 6 分 49.2 秒内吃掉了 50 个卡罗莱纳收割者辣椒，这是世界上最辣的辣椒，斯科维尔热单位为 1.64m。作为比较，墨西哥胡椒;拥有; 2,500 到 8,000 SHU。

;

;视频 ;由吉尼斯世界纪录在线发布;显示杰克戴着红色头巾他戴着手套，在风扇前狼吞虎咽地吃辣椒，有时紧紧地闭上眼睛，喘着粗气。可以听到旁观者为他欢呼并喊道：“加油，迈克！”

;

;杰克吃完 50 个辣椒后（平均每八秒吃一个），他又吃了 85 个。

;

; p>;

;杰克总共吃掉了 135 颗卡罗莱纳收割机。这一特技帮助他在《火焰联盟》收割者挑战者排行榜上取得了;第二名;，该排行榜追踪了最多的收割者挑战者排行榜。卡罗莱纳州收割者一口气吃完。

;

;在向吉尼斯世界纪录讲述他的经历时，杰克 ;说;，“第一个辣椒是最糟糕的。”

;

;“最初的辣味冲击很强烈。第二个看起来没那么糟糕，但随着辣椒接触到你嘴里的新地方，之后的每一个都会变得越来越辣。”

;

;尽管在过去的二十年里建立了对香料的耐受性，杰克说他仍然感到胃部不适。

;

;“我严重痉挛。感觉就像有人在挤压和扭曲我的内脏……你的大脑告诉你停止，但你必须说服自己继续坚持下去，”他说。

;

;杰克是其他几个;记录;，一个是喝一瓶辣酱的最快时间为 8.56 秒，另一个是喝 1 升（约四分之一加仑）番茄酱的最快时间为 1 分 5.56 秒。

;

;早些时候今年，他还打破了世界;最长的哈瓦那辣椒吻记录;，他和妻子吃了哈瓦那辣椒并接吻了15分6.5秒。

;Busingye 似乎对以下证据不屑一顾： 2018年，12名难民在卢旺达被警察枪杀。他说：“是的，这可能发生了，但那又怎样呢？”这位大使本周末在回答《观察家报》的提问时表示，卢旺达西部发生的致命枪击事件是一场悲剧。

;

;“他们应该有一个长期的想法，”他说。 “他们应该制定一项长期政策，让人们可以选择不要冒着生命危险来到英国。因为现在，很多人因为他们国家的战争而没有来到这里。不，他们来这里是因为他们绝望了。他们来到这里是因为他们没有未来。”

;

;他表示，英国将自己视为一个富有同情心的国家是“不道德的”。 “这个国家仍然将自己视为难民国家、安慰国家、保护国家、同情国家，这是不道德的，”他说。 “他们奴役了数百万人 400 年。他们摧毁了印度，他们摧毁了中国，他们摧毁了非洲。”

;

;刚果难民在卡隆吉地区联合国难民事务高级专员办事处外抗议，因削减开支而被枪杀，媒体对此进行了报道，大使似乎感到不安2018 年 2 月，他们向口粮发放了口粮。

;

;他说：“嗯，2012 年发生了一起事件，警察枪杀了 10 名难民。是的，这可能发生了，但那又怎样呢？在英国，每天都有人被枪杀，BBC 上到处都有报道。”

;

;大使本周末表示，他弄错了枪击事件的年份。据 ;人权观察组织的报告。;

;

;在会议期间，大使似乎不愿意明确保证任何从英国运送到卢旺达的难民将永远不会返回自己的祖国

;

;他说：“即使发生了，万一发生了，又会发生多少次呢？还有光天化日之下？我们有英国和卢旺达双重监督委员会。它非常独立。”布辛耶于 2022 年 3 月被确认为卢旺达高级专员，这是大使级任命，尽管遭到了包括前保守党领袖伊恩·邓肯·史密斯在内的一些议员的反对。

;

;

;Led By Donkeys 成立了一家假东南亚公司，并就投资卢旺达事宜与公共事务机构 Chelgate 接洽。这家总部位于伦敦的企业与卢旺达政府有联系，其董事长特伦斯·法恩-桑德斯(Terence Fane-Saunders)在国际谴责鲁塞萨巴吉纳被拘留期间为布辛耶提供了建议。 25 年刑期减刑后，他于 3 月份获释。

;

;其中包括媒体培训、安排记者访问以及在布辛耶担任司法部长时就 Rusesabagina 拘留事件接受半岛电视台电视采访提供建议。这次会议的录像后来无意中被发送到半岛电视台。费恩-桑德斯在网上通话中表示，他认为鲁塞萨巴吉纳被绑架了。他说：“卢旺达情报部门听说他包租了这架飞机……他们与飞机安排在基加利停留……这很有趣。绑架的定义。我的意思是，从技术上讲，我认为这是一次绑架。”

;

; Sun, 01 Oct 2023 03:52:01 +0800 Travel website Booking.com leaves hoteliers thousands of dollars out of pockethttps://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/oct/01/booking-com-hotel-fees-unpaid-millions-technical-issue

;旅游网站 Booking.com 已离开全球许多酒店运营商和其他合作伙伴连续几个月自掏腰包数千美元，并将未付款归咎于“技术问题”。

;

;通常，如果客户通过 Booking.com 网站预订酒店并选择付款在前面，该网站接收付款并将其转给酒店运营商，并扣除佣金。

;

;Booking.com 的合作伙伴自 7 月份以来就报告了接收付款的问题，有时甚至是几个月前。虽然 Booking.com 继续收取客户付款，但该公司并不总是将欠款转嫁给酒店经营者和《卫报》采访过的其他人。

;
;

;;相关：;;“对于造成的混乱，我深表歉意”：旅游公司Tui推出人工智能导游;

;

;

;Loren Infeld 在泰国帕岸岛经营旅馆，他在那里工作了 20 年。 Booking.com 于 4 月中旬停止向这位美国公民支付其中一间旅馆的费用。

;

;“有一大笔费用被延迟，与其余部分分开，然后所有付款都消失了。所以六个月没有付款。”他告诉《卫报》。

;

;Infeld 租下了劳德满月海滩酒店 (Loud: A Full Moon Beach Hotel) 所在的大楼。 Booking.com 停止付款后，他说他被迫自掏腰包支付租金和其他费用，直到只剩下最后 3 美元。

;
;
;

;'有没有办法联系他们。网上说你必须与财务或信用控制部门联系，他们都没有电话号码或电子邮件地址

;
;

;

;这导致许多人尝试其他方式联系该公司，包括 LinkedIn 消息传递、将电子邮件发送给 Booking 集团首席执行官以及查找个人财务官员在线。

;

;在巴厘岛经营一栋两居室别墅的澳大利亚人艾米丽·斯坦利 (Emily Stanley) 上周通过在 Facebook 上追踪到一名财务官员，成功收回了自 3 月份以来所欠的 11,000 澳元。 .

; ;

;“我觉得这是唯一的原因，因为我尝试了其他一切。我打电话、发电子邮件什么的，但什么也没有。然后有趣的是，在他回复的第二天，钱就到了我的账户里。”

;

;斯坦利说，延迟付款意味着她无法支付自己房屋的租金，因此被迫采取了旅行护理工作，免费提供住宿。

;

;“这是非常艰难的六个月。压力很大，流了很多眼泪。我试图保持半满的状态，但要保持这种负能量真的很难，因为人们总是在你身上走来走去。”

;

;“我们要求您在最短的时间内将[欠]金额发送给我时间是可能的，因为我冒着失去我一生工作的风险！！！” 《卫报》看到拉特在发给 Booking.com 的电子邮件中说道。

;

;其他受影响的人包括旅游博主和网站，当客户点击其网站上的链接时，这些网站将获得联属付款。

;“We understand the frustration of the accommodation hosts and owners that have been unduly affected by an ongoing technical issue and can confirm that the system errors that affected the payments have now been corrected and the transactions of most of our partners have been processed,” the spokesperson said.

; Sun, 01 Oct 2023 03:22:01 +0800 Government shutdown could hurt weather disaster responses, Fema sayshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/30/fema-government-shutdown-weather-disasters
;;2023-09-30T18:30:42Z;
;
;;An orange school bus drives through water more than halfway up its tires in a dreary and gray landscape.
;

;The potential imminent shutdown of the federal government could hamper responses to any new weather disasters, leave hazardous waste sites uninspected, and stop work at federal Superfund clean-up sites, according to Democratic House members.

;

;“Federal emergency management agency (Fema) staff will still respond to emergencies, but all long-term projects will be delayed due to a lack of funding in the disaster relief fund,” ;warned the Illinois Democrat Lauren Underwood ;on Friday.

;

;Underwood warned that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will stop inspecting most hazardous waste sites, as well as drinking water and chemical facilities. Also affected, she added, would be efforts to contain polyfluoroalkyl substances – “forever” chemicals, or PFAS – and cleanup activities at Superfund sites.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Senate and House gather in last-ditch effort to avert shutdown at midnight;

;
;

;The warnings come a day after New York was hit by torrential rains that shut down parts of the city's mass-transit system, flooded parts of Brooklyn and triggered the state governor, Kathy Hochul, to declare a state of emergency.

;

;Wide-ranging impacts of a federal freeze come amid warnings that there is little left in the primary government relief fund, after 23 confirmed US weather events related to the climate disaster so far in 2023 have cost at least $1bn each.

;

;The events included two flooding events, 18 severe storms, one tropical cyclone, one wildfire and one winter storm,; according to the National Centers for Environmental Information;. For comparison, the 1980–2022 annual average was roughly eight events.

;

;;According to data; from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the US has seen more billion-dollar weather disasters in 2023 than in any previously recorded year.

;

;Fema spent an average of $4bn annually between 1992 and 1999 on disaster aid. Since 2000, excluding years that saw disasters like 2005's Hurricane Katrina and the response to Covid-19, the emergency management agency's spending has jumped to around $10bn annually.

;

;With three months of the year to go and disaster costs running at $23bn, the Fema administrator Deanne Criswell; testified before the House transportation and infrastructure subcommittee on emergency management ;last week that the agency would have difficulties responding to any natural disaster in the event of a shutdown.

;

;Criswell pointed to decreasing; funding levels; for the disaster relief fund, climate change and the need for its mitigation, the costs of flood insurance and border security as among the agency's concerns. She also said in her testimony that the agency's mission had become “more challenging”.

;

;“We can no longer really speak of a disaster season. With atmospheric rivers in January to tornadoes and wildfires in December, we now face intensified natural disasters throughout the year, often in places not used to experiencing them,” she said.

;

;Citing the Maui wildfires and the California tropical cyclone, she warned that disasters required outsized funding.

;

;“We are in such a moment today,” Criswell added and said she had instituted an “immediate needs funding” mandate of $16bn.

;

;The agency had already cut off more than $1bn in funding to 1,000 public assistance projects, Criswell said.

;

;The warnings come as the Biden administration directs more funds toward disaster relief and away from reconstruction grants. Fema has already delayed around $2.8bn, including $555m for long-term recovery projects in Florida, $101m in Louisiana and another $74m in California, as its disaster fund dropped to just over $2.4bn, ;the Washington Post reported last week;.

;

;While it is likely the fund will be boosted – disasters affect both red and blue states – Criswell warned that any failure to restock agency disaster relief coffers would leave Fema unable to fund a response to new emergencies.

;

;“It is vital that Fema – and the American people – be able to tap into an adequately funded Disaster Relief Fund so that we can continue to respond as soon as disaster strikes, rebuild in their aftermath and prepare for future disasters,” she said.

; Sun, 01 Oct 2023 01:52:01 +0800 Senate and House gather in last-ditch effort to avert shutdown at midnighthttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/30/us-government-shutdown-congress-senate-kevin-mccarthy
;;2023-09-30T17:00:30Z;
;
;;red traffic lights in front of the US Capitol
;

;The Senate and the House reconvened on Saturday in a last-ditch effort to extend federal funding, with less than 12 hours left to prevent a government shutdown.

;

;The Senate was scheduled to hold a vote at 1pm ET on a stopgap spending bill, which would keep the government open until 17 November and provide some funding for Ukraine's war efforts as well as disaster relief aid. Unless both chambers of Congress can pass a stopgap bill, known as a continuing resolution, before midnight, the government will shut down.

;

;Meanwhile, in the House, the Republican speaker, Kevin McCarthy, was moving forward on Saturday with a separate stopgap bill that would also extend funding through 17 November and allocate $16bn for disaster aid. The House bill does not include additional funding for Ukraine, which has become a source of outrage among hard-right lawmakers.

;
;

;;Related: ;;What does a US shutdown mean? Seven things you should know;

;
;

;McCarthy will introduce the bill under suspension of the rules, meaning he will need the support of two-thirds of House members to advance the proposal. Given that high threshold, McCarthy will need some Democratic votes to get the bill passed.

;

;“I do not believe the American public should be punished, so I want to keep government open,” McCarthy told reporters on Saturday morning. “What I am asking Republicans and Democrats alike: put your partisanship away, focus on the American public.”

;

;The lack of Ukraine funding in McCarthy's bill will be a sore spot for Democrats, but time is against them. Even if the Senate advances its bill, the upper chamber will not be able to move to a final vote until Sunday, due to procedural hurdles. Because of the ticking clock, McCarthy's proposal may represent the best option to avoid a shutdown at midnight.

;

;“The Senate cannot bring us a bill before shutdown,” McCarthy said. “Government will shut down if we wait. I do not want that on our watch.”

;

;The rare weekend session comes one day after the House failed to pass McCarthy's initial stopgap bill, which would have extended government funding for another month while enacting steep spending cuts on most federal agencies.

;

;McCarthy's proposal was rejected by 21 House Republicans, as hard-right members continued to insist they will not support a continuing resolution. It appeared unlikely that those members would back McCarthy's new stopgap proposal on Saturday, which would force the speaker to rely even more on Democratic support to get the bill passed. Hard-right Republicans have threatened to oust the speaker if he teams up with Democrats to keep the government open, but McCarthy downplayed that threat on Saturday.

;

;“If somebody wants to remove [me] because I want to be the adult in the room, go ahead and try,” McCarthy said. “But I think this country is too important.”

;

;Ahead of the Saturday session, the Democratic Senate majority leader, Chuck Schumer, called on McCarthy to embrace bipartisanship to keep the government open.

;

;“The speaker has spent weeks catering to the hard right, and now he finds himself in the exact same position he's been in since the beginning: no plan forward, no closer to passing something that avoids a shutdown,” Schumer said on Friday. “The speaker needs to abandon his doomed mission of trying to please [“Make America Great Again”] extremists, and instead, he needs to work across the aisle to keep the government open.”

;

;The blockade staged by hard-right lawmakers has sparked frustration among more moderate members of their House conference, and even the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell, has urged his party to move forward.

;

;“All this week, and every time we've found ourselves in this situation before, I've offered my colleagues the same warning: shutting down the government doesn't help anybody politically,” McConnell said on Friday. “Congress has an opportunity right now: to pay our servicemembers, border security personnel, and other essential workers, to keep important government functions running.”

;

;As lawmakers remained at an impasse, the federal government was bracing for the possibility of the first shutdown in nearly five years. The White House has warned that a shutdown will force hundreds of thousands of government workers to go without pay, jeopardize access to vital nutritional programs and delay disaster relief projects.

;

;“Extreme House Republicans are solely – solely – to blame for marching us toward a shutdown. That is what we're seeing right now,” Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, said on Friday.

;

;Senator John Fetterman, a Democrat of Pennsylvania, similarly blamed Republicans for a potential shutdown – although he used more colorful language to describe his congressional colleagues.

;

;“The damage to our nation's reputation and critical programming, and chaos for America's families is because of a small group of [Republican] peckerheads in the House,” Fetterman said on Saturday. “This national upheaval is inflicted by choice over nothing except Fox News face time and tributes to the lunatic fringe from their district.”

; Sun, 01 Oct 2023 01:22:01 +0800 Revealed: UK government keeping files on education critics’ social media activityhttps://www.theguardian.com/education/2023/sep/30/revealed-uk-government-keeping-files-on-education-critics-social-media-activity

;
;;Ruth Swailes sitting on a park bench
;

;The Department for Education (DfE) is keeping files monitoring the social media activity of some of the country's leading educational experts, the ;Observer; can reveal.

;

;At least nine experts have uncovered files held on them, some as long as 60 pages. One individual even discovered the department had compiled an Excel spreadsheet in which officials had detailed who she interacted with.

;

;Officials at the DfE also tried to cancel a conference because two of the scheduled speakers had previously criticised government policy.

;

;Ruth Swailes and Aaron Bradbury, co-authors of a bestselling book on early childhood, were told by the organisers of a government-sponsored event for childminders and nursery workers, which they were due to speak at in March, that the DfE planned to cancel the conference just days before it opened because they were deemed to be “unsuitable” headline speakers.

;

;The event was eventually allowed to go ahead after Swailes and Bradbury threatened the department with legal action, although a senior government official was present to “monitor” what they said.

;

;Speaking to the ;Observer;, Bradbury, principal lecturer in early childhood studies at Nottingham Trent University, said: “I received a phone call from the organisers saying there were some concerns about us being speakers. The DfE had decided we were unsuitable because we had been critical of government policy.”

;

;He said: “To be told that we couldn't have this debate felt like we were living in a dictatorship, not a democracy.

;

;“We were due to talk about nurturing and early child development. It wasn't some covert stuff about infiltrating Russia.”

;

;Swailes, an independent consultant who advises schools and nurseries on early years education, was so shocked that she filed a subject access request, requiring the DfE to disclose any documents it held on her.

;

;The results, which she received at the end of the summer, revealed that the department kept a file on her. It included critical tweets she had posted about Ofsted, England's schools inspectorate, and noted that she had “liked” posts promoting guidance on teaching young children that was written by educationists rather than the government.

;

;She said: “They have tried to silence me. What they did could have ruined my livelihood and still has the potential to.”

;

;In support of Swailes, many other education experts who are known for challenging the government have now requested similar information about themselves. At least nine individuals have received what they describe as often very lengthy “files” on their views and social media activity. Some, including headteachers and university academics, are still waiting for responses.

;

;Dr Pam Jarvis, a former teacher and education psychologist who has now retired from Leeds Trinity University, said that her request had returned more than 40 pages of records in which officials had monitored her tweets, focusing in particular on her criticisms of the department's controversial new ;baseline assessments for four-year-olds ;in their first term at school.

;

;She said: “Discovering they have been monitoring me makes me fucking furious. And it also makes me more inclined to go on doing it. They should know I will speak up like this until I am dead.”

;

;One modern languages expert, Carmel O'Hagan, uncovered an email from DfE officials accusing her of having “an axe to grind” on Twitter, now rebranded as X, and an Excel spreadsheet in which the department detailed who she interacted with. She described the emails among officials about her in her 37-page file as “puerile” and “spiteful”.

;

;Dr Ian Cushing, a senior lecturer in critical applied linguistics, whose subject access requests revealed that both the DfE and Ofsted were monitoring him, said: “What is deeply troubling to me is the fact that they spend substantial amounts of time and money in these surveillance procedures at a time when schools are being hit by economic difficulties and cost of living crises.”

;

;Sue Cowley, an education expert who runs training for schools, tweeted her response to the records she had been sent under her name this week: “Excuse my language but WTAF [what the actual fuck] are; ;the DfE doing spending taxpayer money conducting surveillance on critics of government policy on here?”

;

;When asked why the government had been compiling files on the social media activity of its critics, the DfE said it did not comment on individual cases.
